fields.body: Read the book excerpt twice, and write important vocabulary words on the board, to help English language learners absorb the information.

Assign ELL or other challenged learners the Galápagos Marine Reserve case study from the Marine Protected Areas activity Marine Critical Issues: Case Studies. Their familiarity with that case study will support their learning in this activity.

Have students watch Enric Sala's TED talk: Glimpses of a Pristine Ocean at home before beginning this activity. The talk presents a case study of the Line Islands that will help students engage in this activity.

Project the Prehistoric Time Line to take students back to the Mesozoic era when dinosaurs and pterosaurs lived. Have students look at the timeline and name the three periods of the Mesozoic Era: Triassic, Jurassic, and Cretaceous. Discuss where pterosaurs would fit on the timeline. Fossil evidence shows they first appeared 215 mya and died out 65 mya. What else lived on Earth at this time?

For students who need additional support, read information aloud, ask students to restate what they read, and model note-taking strategies. Remember to clarify any difficult concepts, and encourage students to focus on the reasons for extinction and threats to species.
Students can complete this activity without using the Glogster virtual tool. Instead, have students make their posters out of paper, cardboard, and other traditional materials.
A good map should always have a legend, or key. Make sure you read the map legend so you can interpret the information included on the map.
Activate English language learners' prior knowledge about the key topic or concept.

Adapt this activity for large-group instruction. Have students compile the organisms recorded in their datasheets to make a master list of all organisms observed. Students can organize this list on chart paper, in a computer database, or on a spreadsheet. Next, have students select one or more organisms to identify, consulting expert resources, and then produce a species inventory card. Encourage students to include drawings, sketches, and photographs on their cards.
Allow English language learners to demonstrate their content knowledge through exhibits or projects, drawings, graphic organizers, or short responses.

Allow kinesthetic learners to physically delineate their territories in the classroom by walking around their personal space or using their arms to show the boundaries between their space and their classmates’ personal space.
As an alternative, provide small groups with printouts of the ecosystem illustrations and have them work together to discuss and match the names and locations of the 12 ecosystems.
As time allows, challenge students to create additional imaginary organisms for their ecosystems.
Ask teachers to bring in three examples of student work—one excellent sample, one average, and one that is confusing to the teacher—to discuss during your professional development session.

Assess content knowledge separately from language proficiency or writing ability. Assess how well English language learners understand key concepts, how accurate their responses are, and how well they demonstrate the processes they use to respond.
Be careful as you handle ammonia. Ammonia can irritate skin, eyes, and lungs. Wear safety goggles and gloves to handle it.
Brainstorm ways to connect content to your local area. Are there local issues that are similar? Are there local organizations that are concerned with the topic?

Check the database beforehand if you suspect that more than a few students in your class have names that will not show up. If that turns out to be the case, make up a list of names to assign to each student for research.

Complete this activity with a map of another continent. Find Mega Maps of the Americas, Africa, Asia, and Australia & Oceania via the Nat Geo MapMaker Kits program page. You will need to create new examples to use for your country cut-outs and location phrases.

Contact a local university geography, science, or history department to find an expert in a content area. Ask them to prepare a short lecture or to be available to answer questions from your teacher group.
Create a blank class data table using a transparency or the whiteboard so it is easier for each group to share its data with the rest of the class.
Demonstrate electromagnetic interferences so students can observe how the assembled magnetometer behaves. Turn on and off computers, a television, or radio.
Depending on the season, you may choose to use a weather map from another day to show a greater variety of types of weather.

Dry ice is frozen carbon dioxide. Do not touch dry ice with your skin. The temperature of dry ice is so cold that it can cause severe frostbite. As it melts, it changes directly into a gas. Avoid breathing in that carbon dioxide gas.
Either while the Tapejara is created or after, have students draw a picture of it and label the adaptations discussed.

Emphasize to students that prevention and early detection are extremely important to stop invasive species from threatening our ecosystems and resources. Have students brainstorm and list ways to prevent the introduction of invasive species and methods for reporting findings of pests.
Encourage teachers to seek out content resources for their own use, so they can learn more about the topic. See NG Education's Recommended Resources for suggestions.
Encourage teachers to visit one another's classrooms as they teach the same lesson to observe student responses to the lesson.
Encourage teachers to write down the questions their students ask about a topic. When you meet with the teachers, compare their lists of questions and work as a group to write answers.

For Step 2: If you do not have a computer for each small group, project the mapping tools at the front of the class and have each group take turns using the computer to explore their assigned country.
For Step 3, the data collection portion of the activity, try to group students so that each group contains a student that has canine teeth they can measure.
For Step 4, older students can calculate the size of the circles by measuring their maps and using ratios to calculate the circle size using the data in Step 3.

For a collaborative activity, have students use the Australia & Oceania MapMaker Kit. In groups, mark the boundaries of the Great Barrier Reef and Queensland. Then use a highlighter to trace the rivers and their tributaries that lead to the Great Barrier Reef. Ask students to identify how many rivers flow into the reef.

For advanced students, explain the meaning of the levels in the food web illustration:
Level 1 (top-level predator): Animals that are usually not preyed on by other animals as adults.
Level 2 (secondary consumers): Animals that eat animals; animals that eat plants and animals.
Level 3: (primary consumers): Animals that eat plants.
Level 4: (producers): Plants that change energy from the sun into nutrients through photosynthesis.

For advanced students, introduce the compass rose, and use it to mark the top and sides of the Mega Map with the cardinal directions north, south, east, and west. Have students practice using the cardinal directions to describe locations of continents and countries; for example, “Norway is north of Germany.”

For advanced students, introduce the concept of latitude/longitude in degrees/minutes/seconds. Explain that a degree is divided into 60 minutes. One minute can be further divided into 60 seconds. Example: 38°56’23”N, 71°0’36”W

For advanced students, introduce the concepts of the winter solstice, summer solstice, autumnal equinox, and vernal equinox. Have them make connections between the hands-on activity and these special days that correspond to different points in the Earth's orbit.

For blind peer evaluations, which may lead to more valuable feedback, label the space probe designs with numbers. If you have more than one class, you can allow one class to evaluate the probes for another class.

For demonstration purposes, construct a sample game board prior to the start of class and make another one along with students during class. Or, for younger students or classes with limited time, prepare the paper plates in advance by dividing the front and back into six sections and numbering them.
For older students, display the graphic "XXXX" showing the relationship of pterosaurs to dinosaurs, mammals, and birds. Discuss extinction and which animals have survived and exist today.

For step 6, advanced students can create a larger chart and include research on more pterosaurs, listing them in chronological order according to fossil age. Suggestions include Eudimorphodon, Rhamphorynchus, Pteranodon, and Pterodactylus.
For students who have difficulty writing, allow them to draw instead. Have them include what the animals eat, what their habitats are like, and where they lay their eggs in the drawing.
For students who live outside of the United States, follow the same steps using the appropriate districts, provinces, or territories.
For students who need help with listening comprehension, use the printed transcript of the NPR "Ocean Priorities" podcast.

Geographic coordinates like latitude and longitude are sometimes presented in different formats. You can use online tools to convert between types or learn the conversion equations yourself. You can find websites online to show you how.
Give teachers the opportunity to try a hands-on activity as if they were students. Then discuss how they will use it in class.
Have English language learners retell what they did or learned in an activity.

Have advanced students research the Safe Drinking Water Act, a federal law that ensures the quality of drinking water in the United States. Ask students to summarize the Act’s main points and to identify several examples of how it has been implemented since the 1970s and what the 1996 amendments addressed.
Have students present information about their group's ocean predator using presentation or slideshow software.
Have students use the Cornell Note Taking method with the reading passage. Click here to find and download a blank Cornell Note Taking worksheet.
Have students use the Cornell Note Taking method with the reading passage. Click here to find and download a blank Cornell Note Taking worksheet.

Have the class work together to complete the worksheet Mapping Drainage Basins and Rivers for each river: Rhine, Oder, Dnieper, Danube, Volga, and Pechora. If students have difficulty delineating the basins, use the provided map Major Drainage Basins in Europe and only require students to answer the questions.
If possible, take students outside and help them to identify trees or vegetation and whether or not each is native/non-native, harmful/not harmful, or invasive.

If completed Plot Study datasheets are unavailable, direct students to research species lists from a nearby state or national park, or to use one of the resources in For Further Exploration to complete this activity.
If digital software is available at your school and students know how to use it, they can use that instead of conventional art materials to create their crests.

If multiple computers are not available, complete the Mara Lion Identification worksheet as a whole class and provide students with the Lion Database Guide 1: Photographing and Identifying Lions handout for reference.
If needed, model the group assignment by doing the first journal entry as a whole class and then dividing students into eight groups instead of nine.

If possible, after mixing the materials, form multiple comets so small groups can each use a blow dryer and observe a comet. Recruit additional adult volunteers to participate in this activity and assign one adult volunteer per small group.
If possible, have some groups poke two holes and hollow out their eggs. Students may have more success with a lighter egg.
If possible, have students put their campaign ideas into a PowerPoint or other presentation format that will be presented to the rest of the class.
If possible, preteach the vocabulary in activities and lessons. This will help English language learners identify words, place them in context, and remember them.
If possible, start the activity by discussing local water issues and usage, so students can make connections between your local area and the area of the Danube River Basin.

If possible, use an overhead projector to model Step 4 before having students do the hands-on activity in pairs or small groups. Project the images on a display screen as you demonstrate and explain the procedure, movements, and formation of eddies using a glass pie plate or petri dish.
If sticky notes are unavailable, use different colored paper and tape it to the map. Students can also write items on the map using different colored markers.

If students are having difficulty understanding the maps, help them to think about looking at a place from above it. For example, show students a photo of a car that looks like the toy car. Then show a photo of the car from the top. Explain how we can look at things and also places from above, as if we were up high looking down.
If students are using laser pointers, stress the importance of not pointing them at another student or at their own eyes. Lasers can cause permanent damage to the retina of the eye.

If students have difficulty understanding temperatures that are below zero, draw a thermometer on the board and mark where the mercury falls with different temperatures in both Celsius and Fahrenheit. Talk about temperatures on Earth. For example, if you are using Fahrenheit (F), mention 100 degrees F being very warm, 32 degrees F being freezing, 212 degrees F being the boiling point for water, and temperatures below zero being very cold for humans. Then talk about temperatures on another planet, drawing and numbering another thermometer. Students will have trouble imagining such temperature extremes, but they will understand that they are extreme.

If students have difficulty with these terms, you may wish to spend additional time reinforcing the meanings of the words. One way you can do this is by having students write sentences using the vocabulary words in context to demonstrate that they understand the definitions.

If students have difficulty with this activity because they have little to no background on Europe, use the encyclopedic entries listed in the "For Further Exploration" section of this activity and/or atlases to provide them with additional background information.
If students need additional background information on rivers, read aloud the NG Education rivers encyclopedic entry, pp. 1-3, as a class.
If students need additional support, review the main ideas in the video and then allow them to work in pairs on the map activity.

If students need help with the concept of a timeline, have them reenact a familiar timeline. Have a student act out waking up (7:00am), eating breakfast (7:30am), and going to school (8:00am). Work together to draw this as a timeline.
If students require additional or written background information about the Bengal tiger or Siberian tiger, provide them with printouts of the National Geographic Wild Animals website pages.
If students struggle with the worksheet Sailing Through History, cut out objects from the worksheet. Present them two at a time and discuss what the images depict as a whole class.
If time allows, have groups swap positions after the debate. Having students debate both sides of an issue builds their critical thinking and problem-solving skills.
If time allows, have students use the WildCam worksheet to observe and record details from a real field location nearby.

If you and your students live on another continent, use a different MapMaker Kit. MapMaker Kits of Europe, Africa, Asia, and Australia & Oceania are available from the Nat Geo MapMaker Kits program page.

If you cannot get out into the field for step 3, you can have students use the Internet to find information about the cultural and physical characteristics of the place. Students may also be able to use Google Earth to see actual images of the place.
If you do not have a wall map of the world, you can project a transparency outline map of the world on the board and have students draw the routes in different colors.

If you do not have enough space to do the kinesthetic model, you can modify this activity to have students create a string-and-bead solar system model in the classroom by converting astronomical units to a 10 centimeter/AU (4 inch) scale. Students will need a string 4.5 meters long. Have students tie beads in place to represent planetary distances.

Sun 0.0 AU=0 cm

Mercury 0.4 AU=4 cm

Venus 0.7 AU=7 cm

Earth 1.0 AU=10 cm

Mars 1.5 AU=15 cm

Asteroid Belt 2.8 AU=28 cm

Jupiter 5.2 AU=52 cm

Saturn 9.6 AU=96 cm

Uranus 19.2 AU=192 cm

Neptune 30.0 AU=300 cm
If you do not have the time or resources for students to complete the research, you can use the provided answer key to provide the organisms' sizes.

If you have limited computers and/or computer availability: Instead of having students research their own project, select one example for the class to explore in depth. Or, select two examples to research as a class and create a chart comparing and contrasting them.
If you have limited time, have students play the guessing game in pairs or in small groups.
If you laminate the map, you can use dry or wet erase markers instead of regular markers. Additionally, laminating the map ensures that you can reuse it.

If you plan to use a stepladder, always assign another student to hold it steady, and supervise students as they use the stepladder to make sure they do not climb too high or do anything that might cause a fall.
In Step 1, have students create a visual glossary of weather-related terms using pictures cut out of magazines or their own drawings.
In Step 1, use a local food chain example to cement student comprehension.
In Step 1, use a video, animation, or ecosystem diagram to help students visualize the successional stages an ecosystem undergoes after a disturbance.
In Step 1, you may choose to incorporate the concepts of pioneer species, primary succession, secondary succession, and climax community throughout the discussion.
In Step 2, if time is limited, have each group only present one of its assigned MPAs.

In Step 2, some students will draw temperatures straight across the map. Other students may not include temperatures for oceans and other bodies of water. Use this opportunity to correct these common misconceptions.

In Step 2: If students have difficulty with the reading passage on the handout The Mayflower and the Gulf Stream, read aloud the passage and have them track the text with their index fingers as you read.
In Step 3, you can use colored beans, cut up pieces of straws, paper fish, or other objects instead of edible goldfish-shaped crackers.

In Step 4, address any student misconceptions about direct versus indirect sunlight. Dim the lights. Adjust a small flashlight to its most concentrated beam and shine the light on dark paper or a wall. Explain that this is similar to concentrated, direct sunlight during summer months. Then adjust the flashlight to the wide beam and describe it as dispersed, or indirect sunlight during winter months.

In Step 4, provide the following support if students are struggling with creating a realistic coast with multiple uses. Show students the provided example of an imaginary coast and marine protected area. Ask: On our map, where do you think a big city might be located? Draw the city on the map. Continue with other [ideas] such as: a school, a university, a small coastal town, a fishing dock, major ports, a naval port, hotels, and a fish farm.
In Step 5, if only one computer is available, play the Lion Crittercam Simulation Game together as a class and ask volunteers to take turns controlling the jeep.
In Step 5, instead of small group work and discussions, you may choose to turn the Feeding Frenzy activity into a game format with rules and points.

In Step 5, use the NG Education video "I Am From: Poem" from the video gallery "Experiencing Film" to give students more background on the format of an "I Am From" poem and a model of a completed poem.

In Step 6, provide a fill-in-the-blank formula for those students who need help creating the diagram to scale:
My spot = _____
My Jupiter = spot × _____
My Earth = spot × _____

In cartography, large-scale maps usually show a small area with a lot of detail, such as a city map. Small-scale maps usually show a large area, but with little detail, like a map of the United States.
Instead of mapping the classroom, consider mapping the playground and its swings, slides, trees, and other features.
Instead of oral presentations, student work can be recorded using a computer with a microphone, or an audio or video recorder.
Invite teachers of other disciplines to join your professional development session to see how geographic thinking might enhance their teaching.
Invite teachers to share the lesson plans they have used in the past when teaching a topic. Have teachers work together to use the strongest plans to construct a new unit.
Laminate the individual sheets of paper and use dry or wet-erase markers so that you can reuse the map.
Laminate the individual sheets of the map so you can re-use it for several years.

Make a simpler version of the solar eclipse viewer with two thin but stiff pieces of white cardboard. Punch a small, clean pinhole in one piece of cardboard and let the sunlight fall through that hole onto the second piece of cardboard, which serves as a screen, held below it. An inverted image of the sun is formed. To make the image larger, move the screen farther from the pinhole. To make the image brighter, move the screen closer to the pinhole. Do not make the pinhole wide or you will only have a shaft of sunlight rather than an image of the crescent sun. Remember, this instrument is used with your back to the sun. The sunlight passes over your shoulder, through the pinhole, and forms an image on the cardboard screen beneath it. Do not look through the pinhole at the sun.
Make sure students know that laser toner will stain clothing and cannot be removed.

Make sure students understand that each line on the map represents a route that different populations in a lineage followed over a very long period of time. It is not a "hiking trail" that individuals or even populations followed from beginning to end.

Make sure students understand that not all non-native species are invasive and harmful. To reinforce the concept, have them research one or more examples of non-native species, such as soybeans, that are not invasive species.

Make sure students understand that these are only models or visualizations of the relative distances between the planets and the sun. Planets all orbit the sun at different velocities, so they rarely form a straight line from the sun. Instead, they appear somewhere along their orbital paths.

Make sure students understand that this activity is intended to allow them to share their ideas, not to learn correct answers. Students will return to these ideas later to make additions and corrections.
Make sure students wear safety goggles during the entire lab experiment.
Make the learning objectives explicit to English language learners.
Model for English language learners thinking aloud about what you are doing as you complete each task.

Model the writing task and show a sample of what is expected. Provide English language learners with a graphic organizer as a prewriting activity to help them organize information and ideas before they write.

Modern grocery stores are sometimes arranged in a more free-form layout than the worksheet suggests. During Step 2, encourage students to adapt the shapes on the worksheet, if needed, or to create their own layout drawing on a separate sheet of paper.
Pair this activity with a water sampling/water quality lab (marine or freshwater) or your biology curriculum's plankton and freshwater plant microscope lab.
Pantomime or act out the scenarios in Step 2 to help visual learners and English language learners gain a clear understanding of each scenario.

Periodically remind students to never look directly at the sun. Make sure students understand they can cause irreversible damage to their eyes without using the proper equipment and techniques to view the sun.

Pre-teach some of the vocabulary—including evaporation, condensation, and precipitation—to help students, especially English language learners, identify words, place them in context, and remember them.

Print the worksheet Draw Political Borders on transparency paper. Cut the transparency into quarters and place the maps on top of one another to show students the interplay of physical and cultural features.
Provide English language learners with sentence starters for both oral and written responses.
Put teachers in groups with mixed grade levels, and ask them to discuss how a topic can be addressed at each grade level to build student understanding.
Read aloud the first-person accounts for auditory learners or struggling readers.
Refer to African Savanna Background Information and Big Cats Background Information for additional content information.
Refer to Big Cats Background Information and the Big Cats and Their Habitats Worksheet and Answer Key for additional information about big cats and their habitats.
Refer to Big Cats Background Information for additional background information.

Reinforce latitude and longitude with jumping jacks to help students distinguish between them. Have students do ten jumping jacks. When you say "latitude," students should move their arms parallel to the floor. When you say "longitude," students should position their arms straight up from the body.
Relate material to English language learners' lives whenever possible.
Restate difficult ideas or content in different ways. Ask clarifying questions to check English language learners' understanding.

Similes, metaphors, and idioms are difficult for English language learners. Avoid them when possible. If they are an integral part of the content, provide additional time and support for these students as you move through the activity.
Simplify Step 4 for students in younger grades. Instead of using the chord bisector method, have them trace, cut, and fold the circle in half. Then measure that line to establish diameter.
Some local malls make their maps available online. If helpful, use a projector to display the online map for students and make this a whole-class activity.
Students can complete this activity without using the Museum Box virtual tool. Instead, have students make their displays out of paper, cardboard, and other traditional materials.

Students can use the maps from the website The Hudson: The River That Defined America, or they can use other map resources. Encourage students to label any other places on the map they encounter on the website and in the video, including the port city of Amsterdam, the Netherlands, which is where Henry Hudson left from.

Sunspot graph data will fluctuate depending on the solar activity of the day. The calculations for the chart should leave students with an average rotational period of between 25 and 36 days. You may want to check the current solar activity before you set up the activity. If there isn't enough for students to track, select a date range on the SOHO website that will provide enough sunspot activity for them to track.
The case studies can be presented orally or in writing.
This activity can be used as a long-term project if your class pursues the opportunity to change the land use of a vacant lot.

This activity contains content-area reading and listening. Support students who have difficulty comprehending some of the text by providing scaffolding such as reinforcing vocabulary concepts, using words in context, predicting, summarizing and clarifying key points, and modeling comprehension strategies.
This activity is designed as an outdoor activity. To adapt it for inside, ask students to observe and record objects rather than wildlife specimens.

This activity uses photographs from different countries and regions of Europe. You may choose to use photographs from one country or one region. If so, use provided worksheet Make Observations: One Country or Region.
To make this activity more "green," use round fruit instead of polystyrene foam balls.

To make this activity more hands-on, and to help your kinesthetic learners, obtain examples of the actual instruments from the school science lab or other teachers. Allow students to touch and examine them.
To shorten this activity to one hour, work with the art teacher ahead of time. Have students create their pictures in art class first. Then display them in your classroom.

To show an ecosystem in balance, periodically take sharks out of the simulation and make sure students understand that they represent sharks that leave an ecosystem because they die. Bring those students back into the simulation as newly born turtles or dugongs.
Try turning on and off different layers with the interactive map tool. Change the transparency of the layers to explore patterns between them.
Use other accounts of research in the news to tie this topic to current events.
Use photographs, real objects, maps, or personal experiences to introduce a key topic or concept to English language learners.
Use simple cognates to help English language learners understand vocabulary terms. Point out any false cognates and provide the correct translation.
Use the Impact of Seafood interactive to research locally fished species.
Use the drawing tools on top of the black and white outline maps to mark up your map with notes, symbols, and hand drawn shapes and lines.
Use visuals, artifacts, and gestures that will make the meaning of academic vocabulary words clear to English language learners.

When creating a choropleth map, organize your data into different categories and apply a color palette to represent the data. Try using the Color Brewer website to categorize and apply color to your dataset.
When creating a graduated symbol map, it is important to create your size range carefully. If you are using circles, they need to be easily distinguishable.
When creating the title of a map, remember to include information that describes where, what, and when.

When deciding on a color scheme for your map, take into account the connotations colors have in different cultures, the accessibility of your map for color-blind users, and how easy it will be to read if photocopied in black and white.
When doing physical activities with the cardinal directions, check to make sure that students do not equate north with "up" or south with "down."
When including map scale, use easy-to-understand increments, such as 0, 5, 10, and 15. Remember to include the unit, such as kilometers, feet, or miles.
When introducing a new activity or lesson to teachers, ask them to predict how their students might respond to each question.
When making maps, keep it simple. Think about the purpose of the map and the intended audience.

When reading a map, look for the data source. You can usually find it along the bottom of a map on the left or right. Knowing the data source is important because it allows you to assess whether the map includes data from a credible source. Try tracking down the original data source yourself. It might include extra information—or metadata—that will help you to become a more informed map reader and researcher.
When working with maps, use the scale bar to engage students with the content of the map. Using the scale bar, students can measure the real-world distance between places on the map.
When working with maps, use the scale bar to engage students with the content of the map. Using the scale bar, students can measure the real-world distance between places on the map.

When you work with geographic coordinates, such as latitude and longitude, make sure you know what format the coordinates are in and how to convert between types. Latitude and longitude often appear in two different formats—decimal degrees or degrees/minutes/seconds.
Write Dr. Earle's quote on a poster board and display it in the classroom a couple of days before ocean instruction begins.
Write important vocabulary words on the board to help English language learners absorb the information.
You can adapt the activity for different MapMaker Kit sizes as needed for different settings.

You can also have students do this activity in small groups. For each group, print one copy of each worksheet on card stock and cut out the cards. One at a time, project and scroll through the two photo galleries, providing groups with enough time to read aloud cards and identify descriptive clues before matching descriptions to photos.
You can also use this activity in English Language Arts classes to focus on word origin, word families, spelling, and related vocabulary skills.
You can use Lesson 10 as a summative assessment for the full unit.

You may choose to modify the activity as needed based on time constraints, group sizes, and student background knowledge. For example, the organisms and ecosystems used can be based on those provided in Lesson 2: Marine Ecosystems and Biodiversity.

You may want to start the activity by first making a connection to your own country’s borders. For example, show a map of the United States and discuss why borders in the United States are located where they are, including both physical and cultural reasons.

If students already have sufficient background on Europe, divide them into groups of four and ask each student to draw a different map based on only one of the following: political borders; cultural groups; physical geography; or historical change. Then have each student share his or her map with their small group, giving others in the group a chance to comment or add to the map. Finally, have the group make a list of questions that they have about Europe, and a list of things that they already know about Europe. Save the maps and lists for use in later lessons in this unit.

fields.definition: The ocean is the dominant physical feature on our planet Earth—covering approximately 70% of the planet’s surface. There is one ocean with many ocean basins, such as the North Pacific, South Pacific, North Atlantic, South Atlantic, Indian and Arctic.
fields.name: Principle 1a

fields.definition: An ocean basin’s size, shape and features (such as islands, trenches, mid-ocean ridges, rift valleys) vary due to the movement of Earth’s lithospheric plates. Earth’s highest peaks, deepest valleys and flattest vast plains are all in the ocean.
fields.name: Principle 1b

fields.definition: Throughout the ocean there is one interconnected circulation system powered by wind, tides, the force of the Earth’s rotation (Coriolis effect), the Sun, and water density differences. The shape of ocean basins and adjacent land masses influence the path of circulation.
fields.name: Principle 1c

fields.definition: Sea level is the average height of the ocean relative to the land, taking into account the differences caused by tides. Sea level changes as plate tectonics cause the volume of ocean basins and the height of the land to change. It changes as ice caps on land melt or grow. It also changes as sea water expands and contracts when ocean water warms and cools.
fields.name: Principle 1d

fields.definition: Most of Earth’s water (97%) is in the ocean. Seawater has unique properties: it is saline, its freezing point is slightly lower than fresh water, its density is slightly higher, its electrical conductivity is much higher, and it is slightly basic. The salt in seawater comes from eroding land, volcanic emissions, reactions at the seafloor, and atmospheric deposition.
fields.name: Principle 1e

fields.definition: The ocean is an integral part of the water cycle and is connected to all of the earth’s water reservoirs via evaporation and precipitation processes.
fields.name: Principle 1f

fields.definition: The ocean is connected to major lakes, watersheds and waterways because all major watersheds on Earth drain to the ocean. Rivers and streams transport nutrients, salts, sediments and pollutants from watersheds to estuaries and to the ocean.
fields.name: Principle 1g

fields.definition: Although the ocean is large, it is finite and resources are limited.
fields.name: Principle 1h

fields.definition: Many earth materials and geochemical cycles originate in the ocean. Many of the sedimentary rocks now exposed on land were formed in the ocean. Ocean life laid down the vast volume of siliceous and carbonate rocks.
fields.name: Principle 2a

fields.definition: Sea level changes over time have expanded and contracted continental shelves, created and destroyed inland seas, and shaped the surface of land.
fields.name: Principle 2b

fields.definition: Erosion—the wearing away of rock, soil and other biotic and abiotic earth materials—occurs in coastal areas as wind, waves, and currents in rivers and the ocean move sediments.
fields.name: Principle 2c

fields.definition: Sand consists of tiny bits of animals, plants, rocks and minerals. Most beach sand is eroded from land sources and carried to the coast by rivers, but sand is also eroded from coastal sources by surf. Sand is redistributed by waves and coastal currents seasonally.
fields.name: Principle 2d

fields.definition: Tectonic activity, sea level changes, and force of waves influence the physical structure and landforms of the coast.
fields.name: Principle 2e

fields.definition: The ocean controls weather and climate by dominating the Earth’s energy, water and carbon systems.
fields.name: Principle 3a

fields.definition: The ocean absorbs much of the solar radiation reaching Earth. The ocean loses heat by evaporation. This heat loss drives atmospheric circulation when, after it is released into the atmosphere as water vapor, it condenses and forms rain. Condensation of water evaporated from warm seas provides the energy for hurricanes and cyclones.
fields.name: Principle 3b

fields.definition: The El Niño Southern Oscillation causes important changes in global weather patterns because it changes the way heat is released to the atmosphere in the Pacific.
fields.name: Principle 3c

fields.definition: Most rain that falls on land originally evaporated from the tropical ocean.
fields.name: Principle 3d

fields.definition: The ocean dominates the Earth’s carbon cycle. Half the primary productivity on Earth takes place in the sunlit layers of the ocean and the ocean absorbs roughly half of all carbon dioxide added to the atmosphere.
fields.name: Principle 3e

fields.definition: The ocean has had, and will continue to have, a significant influence on climate change by absorbing, storing, and moving heat, carbon and water.
fields.name: Principle 3f

fields.definition: Changes in the ocean’s circulation have produced large, abrupt changes in climate during the last 50,000 years.
fields.name: Principle 3g

fields.definition: Most of the oxygen in the atmosphere originally came from the activities of photosynthetic organisms in the ocean.
fields.name: Principle 4a

fields.definition: The first life is thought to have started in the ocean. The earliest evidence of life is found in the ocean.
fields.name: Principle 4b

fields.definition: Ocean life ranges in size from the smallest virus to the largest animal that has lived on Earth, the blue whale.
fields.name: Principle 5a

fields.definition: Most life in the ocean exists as microbes. Microbes are the most important primary producers in the ocean. Not only are they the most abundant life form in the ocean, they have extremely fast growth rates and life cycles.
fields.name: Principle 5b

fields.definition: Some major groups are found exclusively in the ocean. The diversity of major groups of organisms is much greater in the ocean than on land.
fields.name: Principle 5c

fields.definition: Ocean biology provides many unique examples of life cycles, adaptations and important relationships among organisms (such as symbiosis, predator-prey dynamics and energy transfer) that do not occur on land.
fields.name: Principle 5d

fields.definition: The ocean is three-dimensional, offering vast living space and diverse habitats from the surface through the water column to the seafloor. Most of the living space on Earth is in the ocean.
fields.name: Principle 5e

fields.definition: Ocean habitats are defined by environmental factors. Due to interactions of abiotic factors such as salinity, temperature, oxygen, pH, light, nutrients, pressure, substrate and circulation, ocean life is not evenly distributed temporally or spatially, i.e., it is “patchy”. Some regions of the ocean support more diverse and abundant life than anywhere on Earth, while much of the ocean is considered a desert.
fields.name: Principle 5f

fields.definition: There are deep ocean ecosystems that are independent of energy from sunlight and photosynthetic organisms. Hydrothermal vents, submarine hot springs, and methane cold seeps rely only on chemical energy and chemosynthetic organisms to support life.
fields.name: Principle 5g

fields.definition: Tides, waves and predation cause vertical zonation patterns along the shore, influencing the distribution and diversity of organisms.
fields.name: Principle 5h

fields.definition: Estuaries provide important and productive nursery areas for many marine and aquatic species.
fields.name: Principle 5i

fields.definition: The ocean affects every human life. It supplies freshwater (most rain comes from the ocean) and nearly all Earth’s oxygen. It moderates the Earth’s climate, influences our weather, and affects human health.
fields.name: Principle 6a

fields.definition: From the ocean we get foods, medicines, and mineral and energy resources. In addition, it provides jobs, supports our nation’s economy, serves as a highway for transportation of goods and people, and plays a role in national security.
fields.name: Principle 6b

fields.definition: The ocean is a source of inspiration, recreation, rejuvenation and discovery. It is also an important element in the heritage of many cultures.
fields.name: Principle 6c

fields.definition: Much of the world’s population lives in coastal areas.
fields.name: Principle 6d

fields.definition: Humans affect the ocean in a variety of ways. Laws, regulations and resource management affect what is taken out and put into the ocean. Human development and activity leads to pollution (such as point source, non-point source, and noise pollution) and physical modifications (such as changes to beaches, shores and rivers). In addition, humans have removed most of the large vertebrates from the ocean.
fields.name: Principle 6e

fields.definition: Coastal regions are susceptible to natural hazards (such as tsunamis, hurricanes, cyclones, sea level change, and storm surges).
fields.name: Principle 6f

fields.definition: Everyone is responsible for caring for the ocean. The ocean sustains life on Earth and humans must live in ways that sustain the ocean. Individual and collective actions are needed to effectively manage ocean resources for all.
fields.name: Principle 6g

fields.definition: The ocean is the last and largest unexplored place on Earth – less than 5% of it has been explored. This is the great frontier for the next generation’s explorers and researchers, where they will find great opportunities for inquiry and investigation.
fields.name: Principle 7a

fields.definition: Understanding the ocean is more than a matter of curiosity. Exploration, inquiry and study are required to better understand ocean systems and processes.
fields.name: Principle 7b

fields.definition: Over the last 40 years, use of ocean resources has increased significantly, therefore the future sustainability of ocean resources depends on our understanding of those resources and their potential and limitations.
fields.name: Principle 7c

fields.definition: New technologies, sensors and tools are expanding our ability to explore the ocean. Ocean scientists are relying more and more on satellites, drifters, buoys, subsea observatories and unmanned submersibles.
fields.name: Principle 7d

fields.definition: Use of mathematical models is now an essential part of ocean sciences. Models help us understand the complexity of the ocean and of its interaction with Earth’s climate. They process observations and help describe the interactions among systems.
fields.name: Principle 7e

fields.definition: Ocean exploration is truly interdisciplinary. It requires close collaboration among biologists, chemists, climatologists, computer programmers, engineers, geologists, meteorologists, and physicists, and new ways of thinking.
fields.name: Principle 7f

fields.definition: How to Use Maps and Other Geographic Representations, Tools, and Technologies to Acquire, Process, and Report Information From a Spatial Perspective
fields.name: Standard 1

fields.definition: Students read a wide range of print and nonprint texts to build an understanding of texts, of themselves, and of the cultures of the United States and the world; to acquire new information; to respond to the needs and demands of society and the workplace; and for personal fulfillment. Among these texts are fiction and nonfiction, classic and contemporary works.
fields.name: Standard 1

fields.definition: The Characteristics, Distribution, and Complexity of Earth’s Cultural Mosaics
fields.name: Standard 10

fields.definition: Students whose first language is not English make use of their first language to develop competency in the English language arts and to develop understanding of content across the curriculum.
fields.name: Standard 10

fields.definition: Institutions evolve in market economies to help individuals and groups accomplish their goals. Banks, labor unions, corporations, legal systems, and not-for-profit organizations are examples of important institutions. A different kind of institution, clearly defined and enforced property rights, is essential to a market economy.
fields.name: Standard 10: Role of Economic Institutions

fields.definition: The Patterns and Networks of Economic Interdependence on Earth’s Surface
fields.name: Standard 11

fields.definition: Students participate as knowledgeable, reflective, creative, and critical members of a variety of literacy communities.
fields.name: Standard 11

fields.definition: Money makes it easier to trade, borrow, save, invest, and compare the value of goods and services.
fields.name: Standard 11: Role of Money

fields.definition: The Processes, Patterns, and Functions of Human Settlement
fields.name: Standard 12

fields.definition: Students use spoken, written, and visual language to accomplish their own purposes (e.g., for learning, enjoyment, persuasion, and the exchange of information).
fields.name: Standard 12

fields.definition: Interest rates, adjusted for inflation, rise and fall to balance the amount saved with the amount borrowed, which affects the allocation of scarce resources between present and future uses.
fields.name: Standard 12: Role of Interest Rates

fields.definition: How the Forces of Cooperation and Conflict Among People Influence the Division and Control of Earth’s Surface
fields.name: Standard 13

fields.definition: Income for most people is determined by the market value of the productive resources they sell. What workers earn depends, primarily, on the market value of what they produce and how productive they are.
fields.name: Standard 13: Role of Resources in Determining Income

fields.definition: How Human Actions Modify the Physical Environment
fields.name: Standard 14

fields.definition: Entrepreneurs are people who take the risks of organizing productive resources to make goods and services. Profit is an important incentive that leads entrepreneurs to accept the risks of business failure.
fields.name: Standard 14: Profit and the Entrepreneur

fields.definition: How Physical Systems Affect Human Systems
fields.name: Standard 15

fields.definition: Investment in factories, machinery, new technology, and in the health, education, and training of people can raise future standards of living.
fields.name: Standard 15: Growth

fields.definition: The Changes That Occur in the Meaning, Use, Distribution, and Importance of Resources
fields.name: Standard 16

fields.definition: There is an economic role for government in a market economy whenever the benefits of a government policy outweigh its costs. Governments often provide for national defense, address environmental concerns, define and protect property rights, and attempt to make markets more competitive. Most government policies also redistribute income.
fields.name: Standard 16: Role of Government

fields.definition: How to Apply Geography to Interpret the Past
fields.name: Standard 17

fields.definition: Costs of government policies sometimes exceed benefits. This may occur because of incentives facing voters, government officials, and government employees, because of actions by special interest groups that can impose costs on the general public, or because social goals other than economic efficiency are being pursued.
fields.name: Standard 17: Using Cost/Benefit Analysis to Evaluate Government Programs

fields.definition: How to Apply Geography to Interpret the Present and Plan for the Future
fields.name: Standard 18

fields.definition: A nation's overall levels of income, employment, and prices are determined by the interaction of spending and production decisions made by all households, firms, government agencies, and others in the economy.
fields.name: Standard 18: Macroeconomy-Income/Employment, Prices

fields.definition: Unemployment imposes costs on individuals and nations. Unexpected inflation imposes costs on many people and benefits some others because it arbitrarily redistributes purchasing power. Inflation can reduce the rate of growth of national living standards because individuals and organizations use resources to protect themselves against the uncertainty of future prices.
fields.name: Standard 19: Unemployment and Inflation

fields.definition: Productive resources are limited. Therefore, people can not have all the goods and services they want; as a result, they must choose some things and give up others.
fields.name: Standard 1: Scarcity

fields.definition: How to Use Mental Maps to Organize Information About People, Places, and Environments in a Spatial Context
fields.name: Standard 2

fields.definition: Students read a wide range of literature from many periods in many genres to build an understanding of the many dimensions (e.g., philosophical, ethical, aesthetic) of human experience.
fields.name: Standard 2

fields.definition: Federal government budgetary policy and the Federal Reserve System's monetary policy influence the overall levels of employment, output, and prices.
fields.name: Standard 20: Monetary and Fiscal Policy

fields.definition: Effective decision making requires comparing the additional costs of alternatives with the additional benefits. Most choices involve doing a little more or a little less of something: few choices are "all or nothing" decisions.
fields.name: Standard 2: Marginal Cost/Benefit

fields.definition: How to Analyze the Spatial Organization of People, Places, and Environments on Earth’s Surface
fields.name: Standard 3

fields.definition: Students apply a wide range of strategies to comprehend, interpret, evaluate, and appreciate texts. They draw on their prior experience, their interactions with other readers and writers, their knowledge of word meaning and of other texts, their word identification strategies, and their understanding of textual features (e.g., sound-letter correspondence, sentence structure, context, graphics).
fields.name: Standard 3

fields.definition: Different methods can be used to allocate goods and services. People acting individually or collectively through government, must choose which methods to use to allocate different kinds of goods and services.
fields.name: Standard 3: Allocation of Goods and Services

fields.definition: The Physical and Human Characteristics of Places
fields.name: Standard 4

fields.definition: Students adjust their use of spoken, written, and visual language (e.g., conventions, style, vocabulary) to communicate effectively with a variety of audiences and for different purposes.
fields.name: Standard 4

fields.definition: People respond predictably to positive and negative incentives.
fields.name: Standard 4: Role of Incentives

fields.definition: That People Create Regions to Interpret Earth’s Complexity
fields.name: Standard 5

fields.definition: Students employ a wide range of strategies as they write and use different writing process elements appropriately to communicate with different audiences for a variety of purposes.
fields.name: Standard 5

fields.definition: Voluntary exchange occurs only when all participating parties expect to gain. This is true for trade among individuals or organizations within a nation, and among individuals or organizations in different nations.
fields.name: Standard 5: Gain from Trade

fields.definition: How Culture and Experience Influence People’s Perceptions of Places and Regions
fields.name: Standard 6

fields.definition: Students apply knowledge of language structure, language conventions (e.g., spelling and punctuation), media techniques, figurative language, and genre to create, critique, and discuss print and nonprint texts.
fields.name: Standard 6

fields.definition: When individuals, regions, and nations specialize in what they can produce at the lowest cost and then trade with others, both production and consumption increase.
fields.name: Standard 6: Specialization and Trade

fields.definition: The Physical Processes That Shape the Patterns of Earth’s Surface
fields.name: Standard 7

fields.definition: Students conduct research on issues and interests by generating ideas and questions, and by posing problems. They gather, evaluate, and synthesize data from a variety of sources (e.g., print and nonprint texts, artifacts, people) to communicate their discoveries in ways that suit their purpose and audience.
fields.name: Standard 7

fields.definition: Markets exist when buyers and sellers interact. This interaction determines market prices and thereby allocates scarce goods and services.
fields.name: Standard 7: Markets—Price and Quantity Determination

fields.definition: The Characteristics and Spatial Distribution of Ecosystems on Earth’s Surface
fields.name: Standard 8

fields.definition: Students use a variety of technological and informational resources (e.g., libraries, databases, computer networks, video) to gather and synthesize information and to create and communicate knowledge.
fields.name: Standard 8

fields.definition: Prices send signals and provide incentives to buyers and sellers. When supply or demand changes, market prices adjust, affecting incentives.
fields.name: Standard 8: Role of Price in Market System

fields.definition: The Characteristics, Distribution, and Migration of Human Population on Earth’s Surface
fields.name: Standard 9

fields.definition: Students develop an understanding of and respect for diversity in language use, patterns, and dialects across cultures, ethnic groups, geographic regions, and social roles.
fields.name: Standard 9

fields.definition: Competition among sellers lowers costs and prices, and encourages producers to produce more of what consumers are willing and able to buy. Competition among buyers increases prices and allocates goods and services to those people who are willing and able to pay the most for them.
fields.name: Standard 9: Role of Competition
